LEHIGH WINS SOUTHERN LACROSSE TITLE
Defeats Hopkins in Easy Game by 12to-2 Count. To Play Syracuse for
Championship. Stuart and
Parsons Shoot Hopkins
Goals.

For the second successive year
ehigh won the intercollegiate lacrosse title of the So'uthern division
by defeating Hopkins, 12 to 2, at
bethlehem, on Saturday. Lehigh
now has the right to play Syracuse,
winner of the Northern division, for
the intercollegiate title.
Saturday's game started out with
prospects of a close battle, but goals
by Bertolet and Strouch soon put
Lehigh ahead, the half ending 5 to
1. Hopkins rallied at the beginning of the second half and shot
two goals in quick succession. One
of these was not allowed, however,
because a man was in the crease.
Lehigh then got going and began
shooting goals in quick succession,
Hopkins' defense being unable to
stop their speedy attacks. Lehigles
defense,. on the other hand, played
a star game and whenever Hopkins
was able to *work the ball down the
field they were checked at all times.
Parker, at goal, stopped several
seeming goals, playing his position
in great style.

At its banquet held last Friday
night at the Hotel Emerson, the
Dramatic Club elected the following men as officers for the coming
year:
Gilson Engle, '22, President.
Eli Frank, Jr., 22, Secretary.
H. Pierce Brawner, '23, Treasurer.
The office of Production Manager will be held open until the nex
ager will be held open until next

L. Terry Burger, '20, Donald S.
Mossour, '21, Frank R. Smith, Jr.,

to compile the material and finance

book will contain the music and
words of approximately sixteen or
more of the best and most distinctive Hopkins songs. It is probable

be included. The compilation and
arrangement of the editorial matter will be in the hands of "Mike"
Bowers and "Tom" Hubbard, who

form. They will be assisted by Dr.

and the other assemblies. The circle is discussing plans to make its
program attractive and at the same
time an active force in the development of undergraduate life and
spirit. This, it believes, is the primary reason for the existence of
the assemblies.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 31, 1921

SCIENTIFIC CLUB

On Wednesday, May 25, Mr.
Henry T. Wenzel, Instructor of
Physics at the University, delivered an interesting lecture on the
Structure of the Atom and the
Electron Theory as it applies to
Chemistry at present.
The lecture was well attended
and brought to a close a very successful season. A number of prominent speakers have given interesting lectures and the members
of the club feel that they have
been benefited very much.
Next year the club intends to
extend its activities on a large
scale. It proposes to give a series
of lectures by prominent speakers, corresponding to a series of
lectures in literature. These are to
be given at night in the C. E.
Bldg. and are to be open to the
public.

HOPKINS SCORES EASY VICTORY OVER WESTERN
MARYLAND
Visitors Saved from Shut-out by 2 Runs
in Ninth. "Buck" Grace Featured
for the Home Team.

Ten to two in favor of Hopkins
was the final score of the baseball
game with Western Maryland on
Wednesday, May 25. The game
was one-sided throughout and
consequently devoid of thrills.
Tucker hurled well for the Black
and Blue nine and had excellent
support. The feature of the game
was the fielding of "Buck" Grace,
Hopkins' snappy second sacker,
who plucked three burning line
drives from the air that would
otherwise probably have made
scores for the lads from Westminster. Keen also, in his handling
of. the first base position, showed
fine form. In the eighth inning
"Mike" Levin was run into our
battery as catcher and "Bobby"
Owings w,as placed in right field.
The visitors registered but 5 hits
during the game and scored their
two runs in the ninth inning on a
two-base hit by Long.

SOCIAL SCIENCE CLUB BANQUETS AT HOIVIEWOOD

NEWS-LETTER TO BECOME
SEMI-WEEKLY

Ambitious Plans for Next Year Adopted. Dr. Lovejoy Is Speaker.

Will Adopt Changed Policy Next Year.
Will Appear on Tuesdays and
Fridays.

The Social Science Club held a
thoroughly successful banquet
last Thursday night at the Johns
Hopkins Club. Drs. Lovejoy and
Mitchel were the faculty members present. The former delivered an intensely interesting address in which he said that the
club was the most important student organization on the campus
because it is "the only outward
manifestation that students are
thinking of what is now of paramount importance: namely, the
social sciences or the art of living
together on this planet." Dr. Lovejoy gave a rapid sketch of the difficulties in which the world in
general now finds itself and pointed'out that the club is helping its
members face these problems with
more understanding. Dr. Mitchel
spoke of the work that is being
done in Baltimore by people interested in social service.
The club intends to enter a vigorous campaign for a larger.
membership next year and plans
were formulated for giving the
students a real insight into what
work the club is doing.
Lively discussion meetings are
planned and everyone, regardless
of his economic beliefs, is welcome. An effort is being made to
bring the most prominent men
possible to the university for the
usual series of public lectures.

According to the recently announced decision of the Board, the
NEWS-LETTER will be issued twice
weekly next year, appearing on
Tuesdays and Fridays.
The Tuesday issue will be devoted primarily to the athletic
games and other activities of the
preceding week-end. The second
issue, on Friday, will deal mainly
in advance information on the contests and other events scheduled
for the next few days.
This bi-weekly policy will enable
the NEWS-LETTER to be up to the
m;nute in reporting all events of interest to the student body. It is
hoped that by calling attention to
activities just before their occurrence, and by reporting news before
it has become stale, a greater interest will be aroused in all college
enterprises.
The size of the paper will be
changed so that the new issues will
have more of the newspaper form.
In its new form, the NEWS-LETTER
will consist of two issues of four
pages, 12x19 inches, of five-columns
each. It is hoped that this will allow all the most important happenings to receive their proper place,
on the front page.
Of the total space of twenty columns, about eight will be given
over to advertisements, but the
space still remaining for reading
matter will be at least as large as
at present in the eight-page issue.
These changes, it is felt, will
make the NEWS
even more
attractive and useful by enabling
it to carry out to a greater degree
it efforts to chronicle faithfully
our college life.
The NEWS-LETTER will continue
to publish the Daily Bulletin.

R. 0. T. C. STAGES DRESS
PARADE
On Thursday, May 26, the R.0.
T. C. carried out an impressive
dress parade on the upper quadrangle. It was followed by a formal guard mount by Company A,
which. was also executed in fine
form. The ceremony was witnessed by a large gathering of the
student body and faculty. The
music for the occasion was furnished by the Camp Holabird
Band, which added greatly to the
effect of the parade. After the
ceremonies a competitive drill in
the manual of arms was held between the men of the 1st year
basic to decide the winner of the
medal for the best drilled private.
It was won after a hard fight by
W. C. Wilgis, whose demonstration was practically perfect.
Major Gary is very well pleased
with the way the students are doing their work and especially by
the way those with absences are
making up their lost time. The
chart in the military office shows
that there are only a few students
with bad marks against their
names, a fact which is most gratifying to the department.
The last drill will be held on
Thursday. There will probably be
a review in honor of Governor
Ritchie, followed by the presentation of the company cup and
other medals. On June 15th all of
the students going to training
camp will leave for Plattsburg.
Seventy men have entered their
names on the roll. This will probably be the largest contingent
from any one college at the camp.
Every one is preparing to do his
best in an effort to win the camp
honors for Hopkins.

STUDENT COUNCIL ELECTIONS
COMPLETED

The Junior, Sophomore and
Freshman classes held meetings last
week for the purpose of electing
their representatives on the Student Council. Next year's senior
class will be represented by Robert C. Hall and Gilson C. Engle,
while the Class of 1923 will be represented by Donald K. Vanneman
and John Marchant. Edward Morrison was elected as representative
of the Class of 1924.
The Student Council will present
a new constitution at the Thursday
assembly to be voted on by the student body. Everyone is urged to
be there so that it may receive the
sanction of as many students as
possible.

Three Men Earn Seal in Two Activities. Cotton to Be Chairman of
Council Next Year.

At a recent meeting of the Varsity Seal Voting Council honorary
awards were made to John Myers,
the postmaster and Fulton R. Bramble, former editor-in-chief of the
Black and Blue Jay. It is gratifying
to note that Mr. Myers' long service
to undergraduate activities at Hopkins has been recognized by an
award which is one of the most coveted honors obtainable at Hopkins.
Those men who received stars for
two activities on their seals are as
follows: E. S. Huey, NEWS-LETTER
and Hullabaloo; F. R. Smith,
NEWS-LETTER and Dramatic Club
R. H. Watkins, Debating and Hullabaloo.
In addition to the above names,
the following were given seals with
one star: NEWS-LETTER—Cotton,
Lipps, Miller, Fallan, C. W. Perkins, Jr., Huey, and F. R. Smith.
Debating—Watkins, Williams, Emmart, and Himand. Hullabaloo—
Watkins and Huey. Musical Clubs
—Bowers, Hambleton, Smallwood.
Scheidt, Vanneman, Parsons, Jacobsen, Kuder, C. S. Collins and E.
M. Spieker (grad. student). Dramatic Club—Basford, Mossom,
West, F. R. Smith and C. H. Boyd.
Honorary Award — John Myers,
Fulton R. Bramble.
For a long time there had been
at the University a growing sentiment in favor of giving some kind
o f recognition to the men who
achieved success in the non-athletic
forms of collegiate activities. Last
year a Varsity Seal Voting Council was instituted, which awards a
Varsity Seal to every man who
qualifies in any of the five major
activities, namely, the Hullabaloo,
the NEWS-LETTER, the Musical
Clubs, the Dramatic Club and the
Debating Team. The government
ot the Varsity Seal Organization is
vested in a council composed of two
men from each of the organizations
whose members are entitled to the
Seal. As a student organization
it is especially desirable because the
requirements for membership are
bid down in a definite set of rules,
thus making it certain that any man
who takes part in Hopkins activities will receive the award without
the possibility that politics will deprive him of that honor.
The award is in the form of a
miniature reproduction in gold of
